Award.AwardTitle: BPC-AE: Collaborative Research: The Alliance for the Advancement of African-American Researcher in Computing (A4RC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University, together with collaborating institutions Clemson University, Prairie View A&M University, the University of Colorado, the University of Wisconsin, Auburn University, the University of Indiana, Norfolk State University, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Fort Valley Sate University, and Jackson State University, proposes an extension of the successful Alliance for the Advancement of African-American Researchers in Computing (A4RC, pronounced "A-Force"). A4RC aims to increase the number of African-Americans obtaining advanced degrees in computing, particularly at the Ph.D. level. A4RC establishes and develops student pipelines from HBCUs to universities offering advanced degrees in Computing. A4RC has amassed a body of knowledge and experience with respect to what it takes to build effective HBCU/R1 faculty collaborations, develop productive HBCU/R1 research teams that include graduate and undergraduate students, and prepare undergraduate and master's students for research at the Ph.D. level. A4RC uses a "research pod" concept that is efficient, flexible, and effective in terms of HBCU/R1 research collaborations. With this extension, A4RC plans to expand the alliance to include a greater number of HBCU/R1 research collaborations, and to build new partnerships. A new category of partners -- Affiliate Partners -- will engage additional HBCUs and national labs and A4RC will become formal partners with the very effective BPC Demonstration Project, African-American Researchers in Computing Sciences (AARCS). A4RC will build collaborations with the BPC STARS and Empowering Leadership Alliances, and ADMI: The Symposium on Computing at Minority Institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Alliance for the Advancement of African-American Researchers in Computing (A4RC) was formed to increase the number African-Americans receiving advanced degrees in computing (particularly at the PhD level). Leveraging a dual feeder model, A4RC strives for high visibility, increased interest, and intentional advising programs that support and promote paths into research careers, and quality research collaborations between HBCUs and research universities. Over the past five years, A4RC has amassed invaluable knowledge and experience with respect to: (a) building effective HBCU/Research 1 (R1) faculty collaborations; (b) developing productive HBCU/R1 research teams that include graduate and undergraduate students; and (c) preparing undergraduate and master’s students for research at the Ph.D. level.

According to evaluation highlights, as a result of their A4RC involvement, students have:
• Have significantly greater intention to pursue both masters and doctoral degrees
• Made positive gains with respect to understanding and doing several aspects of research
• Gained experience with communicating research (posters, conference submissions, presentations)
• Developed a sense of belonging to a community of researchers, feel more strongly committed to their computer science degrees, and take pride in their contributions to the pods
• Have a much deeper understanding of research careers and how to pursue one (along a number of dimensions)

In Phase 2, the membership and scope of HBCUs involved in A4RC increased from 5 to 13. With this expansion potential HBCU CS major student exposure to A4RC goals increased from 645 undergraduate and 175 graduate students in 2006 to 1790 undergraduates and 486 graduate students in 2011. The participation of A4RC students in two key activities that tend to increase the likelihood of graduate school attendance and success, namely involvement in REU or equivalent programs and funded research, has improved significantly during both phases of the grant. Similar success has been measured for student publications and conference presentations.

Due to the time-to-degree dynamic of obtaining a Ph.D. and the length of this project, the measure of success cannot rely solely on degree completion. Rather, we have focused on participation in high-impact activities that tend to lead to graduate school, provide exposure to critical knowledge domains in these high-impact activities, and facilitate application to and enrollment in graduate programs. When using the above criteria, data within this report demonstrate that A4RC has successfully crafted an infrastructure or pathway for undergraduates at HBCUs to gain the necessary knowledge, skills, and dispositions to enroll in graduate programs in computing sciences. A4RC institutions showed modest (e.g., 11-15%) growth in both undergraduate and graduate student enrollment in computing science. The organizational capacity development through A4RC is exemplified through the productivity of A4RC students as well as faculty participants. Through their interactions and experiences with R1 faculty and in R1 labs, both students and faculty alike bring a higher level of research productivity to their home departments at HBCUs. Additionally, these experiences facilitate among students the desire to pursue graduate education, as this goal now seems attainable due to their connections with R1 institutions with graduate programs. Additionally, A4RC institutions have built capacity through articulation agreements with R1s, making provisions for HBCU students to be admitted to R1s upon completion of A4RC and their undergraduate degrees.
